| A coven leader:* can [fly](/wiki/Fly "Fly").
* has [a head, a couple of arms, and a torso](/wiki/Humanoid "Humanoid").
* is [omnivorous](/wiki/Omnivore "Omnivore").
* is not a valid [polymorphable](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") form.
* is a [human](/wiki/Human_\(monster_attribute\) "Human (monster attribute)").
* is a [lord to its kind](/wiki/M2_LORD "M2 LORD").
* is female.
* is [strong](/wiki/Strong "Strong").
* can pick up weapons and food.
* can pick up [magical items](/wiki/Magical_item "Magical item").
* lets you close unless attacked.
* can be seen through [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision").
* cannot be [tamed](/wiki/Scroll_of_taming "Scroll of taming"). |                                                                                       |

A **coven leader**, @, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") and [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack"). The coven leader is a [strong](/wiki/Strong "Strong") [human](/wiki/Human_\(monster_attribute\) "Human (monster attribute)") woman that is capable of [flight](/wiki/Flight "Flight") and [spellcasting](/wiki/DNetHack_monster_spells "DNetHack monster spells"), can be seen via [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision") and will seek out and collect items, particularly [magical items](/wiki/Magical_item "Magical item"). She is a [lord](/wiki/M2_LORD "M2 LORD") to her fellow [witches](/wiki/Witch_\(dNetHack\) "Witch (dNetHack)"), and cannot be [tamed](/wiki/Tamed "Tamed").

A coven leader has a single weapon attack, and will attempt to cast spells clerically once during each of her turns: she can cast [psi bolt](/wiki/Psi_bolt "Psi bolt"), [acid rain](/index.php?title=Acid_rain\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Acid rain (page does not exist)"), [evil eye](/index.php?title=Evil_eye_\(monster_spell\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Evil eye (monster spell) (page does not exist)"), [curse items](/wiki/Curse_items "Curse items"), [summon alien](/wiki/Summon_alien "Summon alien"), [summon devil](/index.php?title=Summon_devil\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Summon devil (page does not exist)"), [touch of death](/wiki/Touch_of_death "Touch of death"), and [drain life](/wiki/Drain_life_\(monster_attack\) "Drain life (monster attack)"), with an equal probability of each. A coven leader can only cast spells if [her familiar](/wiki/Witch%27s_familiar "Witch's familiar") is present, but is able to do so without any cooldown - if her familiar is killed, she gains +8 [encouragement](/index.php?title=Encouragement\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Encouragement (page does not exist)") to damage and to-hit, and will eventually summon another familiar to replace the lost one.

## Generation

Coven leaders are not randomly generated, and are not a valid form for polymorph.

At level creation, a single coven leader is generated in the Temples of the Old Gods within the [Neutral Quest](/wiki/Neutral_Quest_\(dNetHack\) "Neutral Quest (dNetHack)"), with nine [apprentice witches](/wiki/Apprentice_witch "Apprentice witch") and three witches accompanying her. A witch's familiar is generated alongside the coven leader at the same level as her.

A coven leader is [always generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") black [high boots](/wiki/High_boots "High boots"), a [plain dress](/wiki/Plain_dress "Plain dress"), a black set of [leather armor](/wiki/Leather_armor "Leather armor"), a black [magic-resistant](/wiki/Object_properties#Defensive "Object properties") [cloak](/wiki/Plain_cloak "Plain cloak") (*not* a [cloak of magic resistance](/wiki/Cloak_of_magic_resistance "Cloak of magic resistance")), a black [pair of gloves](/wiki/Pair_of_gloves "Pair of gloves"), a [witch hat](/wiki/Witch_hat "Witch hat"), and a [quarterstaff](/wiki/Quarterstaff "Quarterstaff").

## Strategy

The coven leader requires the most care of the witch battalion by far, on top of the familiars' [open wounds](/wiki/Open_wounds "Open wounds") spells cutting at you from across the river. Dealing with the witch battalion generally requires that characters have a high amount of HP and a source of [half spell damage](/wiki/Half_spell_damage "Half spell damage").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Witchcraft](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Witchcraft "wikipedia:Witchcraft")***

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[The Dreams in the Witch House](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Dreams_in_the_Witch_House "wikipedia:The Dreams in the Witch House")***

Witchcraft refers to the alleged use of supernatural or magic powers primarily to inflict harm and misfortune upon others, with practitioners of the art known as "witches". European belief in witchcraft traces back to classical antiquity, with medieval and early modern European cultures playing host to [witch hunting](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Witch_hunt "wikipedia:Witch hunt"): the accused "witches" were usually women believed to have used black magic or maleficium against their own community, with the accusations borne of social tensions and believed by some anthropologists to have been focused on supposed enemies of the Church. Witchcraft is also generally considered malevolent in many indigenous belief systems, with people seeking healers and medicine people for protection against witchcraft. Believed to be driven by evil spirits or substances, suspected historical witches were intimidated, banished, attacked or outright killed - often they would be formally prosecuted and punished if they considered or simply believed to be guilty, resulting in tens of thousands of executions.

Witchcraft in its modern context generally refers to followers of certain types of modern paganism, who self-identify as witches and use the term witchcraft for their beliefs and practices, though some other neo-pagans avoid the term due to its negative connotations. Witches are also depicted in various forms of media as practitioners of magic that can range from empowered humans to almighty sorcerers to monstrous hag-like beings, and there are many instances of a witch "species" separate from mundane humanity. Witches in fairy tales and cartoons, particularly of the "monster" variety, are often depicted as long-nosed crones that are malevolent and seen as hideous witch croaky voices and shrieking laughs - they often wear distinct pointed brimmed hats and are sometimes depicted taking flight, with the stereotypical witch using a broom; many of these qualities are sometimes omitted or even subverted in modern depictions.

The witches of *dNetHack* are mostly based on cultists from the [Cthulhu Mythos](/wiki/Cthulhu_Mythos "Cthulhu Mythos"), such as Keziah Mason from the 1933 [H.P. Lovecraft](/wiki/H.P._Lovecraft "H.P. Lovecraft") short story "The Dreams in the Witch House", who is depicted as a servant of the alien ["Outer Gods"](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outer_Gods "wikipedia:Outer Gods"). Keziah Mason was an old woman who lived in a house in Arkham during the 1692 Salem witch trials, and was one of the many accused witches arrested - in her testimony to the judge, Keziah spoke of "lines and curves that could be made to point out directions leading through the walls of space to other spaces beyond", as well as describing a pitch-black man later revealed to be an avatar of Nyarlathotep. Keziah later disappeared mysteriously from Salem Gaol, leaving behind "curves and angles smeared on the grey stone walls with some red, sticky fluid" that were inexplicable even to the most studied clergymen of the time. Protagonist Walter Gilman, who moved into her former home, begins having bizarre dreams where he falls under Keziah's influence.

[![This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.](/images/5/5d/Nh343var-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.")

Coven leader

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
@ coven leader (No tile)
Difficulty 23
Attacks Weapon 1d6 physical, Cast 2d6 clerical spell
@ coven leader (No tile)
Difficulty 23
Attacks

Weapon 1d6 physical, Cast 2d6 clerical spell

Base level 20
Base experience 674
Speed 16
Base AC 2
Base MR 60
Alignment 0 (neutral)
Frequency (by normal means) 0 (Not randomly generated)
Genocidable No
Weight 1450
Nutritional value 400
Size medium

A coven leader:

  • can fly.
  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • is omnivorous.
  • is not a valid polymorphable form.
  • is a human.
  • is a lord to its kind.
  • is female.
  • is strong.
  • can pick up weapons and food.
  • can pick up magical items.
  • lets you close unless attacked.
  • can be seen through infravision.
  • cannot be tamed.

A coven leader, @, is a type of monster that appears in dNetHack and notdNetHack. The coven leader is a strong human woman that is capable of flight and spellcasting, can be seen via infravision and will seek out and collect items, particularly magical items. She is a lord to her fellow witches, and cannot be tamed.

A coven leader has a single weapon attack, and will attempt to cast spells clerically once during each of her turns: she can cast psi bolt, acid rain, evil eye, curse items, summon alien, summon devil, touch of death, and drain life, with an equal probability of each. A coven leader can only cast spells if her familiar is present, but is able to do so without any cooldown - if her familiar is killed, she gains +8 encouragement to damage and to-hit, and will eventually summon another familiar to replace the lost one.

Generation

Coven leaders are not randomly generated, and are not a valid form for polymorph.

At level creation, a single coven leader is generated in the Temples of the Old Gods within the Neutral Quest, with nine apprentice witches and three witches accompanying her. A witch's familiar is generated alongside the coven leader at the same level as her.

A coven leader is always generated with black high boots, a plain dress, a black set of leather armor, a black magic-resistant cloak (not a cloak of magic resistance), a black pair of gloves, a witch hat, and a quarterstaff.

Strategy

The coven leader requires the most care of the witch battalion by far, on top of the familiars' open wounds spells cutting at you from across the river. Dealing with the witch battalion generally requires that characters have a high amount of HP and a source of half spell damage.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Witchcraft
Wikipedia has an article about:
The Dreams in the Witch House

Witchcraft refers to the alleged use of supernatural or magic powers primarily to inflict harm and misfortune upon others, with practitioners of the art known as "witches". European belief in witchcraft traces back to classical antiquity, with medieval and early modern European cultures playing host to witch hunting: the accused "witches" were usually women believed to have used black magic or maleficium against their own community, with the accusations borne of social tensions and believed by some anthropologists to have been focused on supposed enemies of the Church. Witchcraft is also generally considered malevolent in many indigenous belief systems, with people seeking healers and medicine people for protection against witchcraft. Believed to be driven by evil spirits or substances, suspected historical witches were intimidated, banished, attacked or outright killed - often they would be formally prosecuted and punished if they considered or simply believed to be guilty, resulting in tens of thousands of executions.

Witchcraft in its modern context generally refers to followers of certain types of modern paganism, who self-identify as witches and use the term witchcraft for their beliefs and practices, though some other neo-pagans avoid the term due to its negative connotations. Witches are also depicted in various forms of media as practitioners of magic that can range from empowered humans to almighty sorcerers to monstrous hag-like beings, and there are many instances of a witch "species" separate from mundane humanity. Witches in fairy tales and cartoons, particularly of the "monster" variety, are often depicted as long-nosed crones that are malevolent and seen as hideous witch croaky voices and shrieking laughs - they often wear distinct pointed brimmed hats and are sometimes depicted taking flight, with the stereotypical witch using a broom; many of these qualities are sometimes omitted or even subverted in modern depictions.

The witches of dNetHack are mostly based on cultists from the Cthulhu Mythos, such as Keziah Mason from the 1933 H.P. Lovecraft short story "The Dreams in the Witch House", who is depicted as a servant of the alien "Outer Gods". Keziah Mason was an old woman who lived in a house in Arkham during the 1692 Salem witch trials, and was one of the many accused witches arrested - in her testimony to the judge, Keziah spoke of "lines and curves that could be made to point out directions leading through the walls of space to other spaces beyond", as well as describing a pitch-black man later revealed to be an avatar of Nyarlathotep. Keziah later disappeared mysteriously from Salem Gaol, leaving behind "curves and angles smeared on the grey stone walls with some red, sticky fluid" that were inexplicable even to the most studied clergymen of the time. Protagonist Walter Gilman, who moved into her former home, begins having bizarre dreams where he falls under Keziah's influence.

A '''coven leader''', {{magenta|@}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in [[dNetHack]] and [[notdNetHack]]. The coven leader is a [[strong]] [[Human (monster attribute)|human]] woman that is capable of [[flight]] and [[dNetHack monster spells|spellcasting]], can be seen via [[infravision]] and will seek out and collect items, particularly [[magical item]]s. She is a [[M2_LORD|lord]] to her fellow [[Witch (dNetHack)|witches]], and cannot be [[tamed]].

A coven leader has a single weapon attack, and will attempt to cast spells clerically once during each of her turns: she can cast [[psi bolt]], [[acid rain]], [[Evil eye (monster spell)|evil eye]], [[curse items]], [[summon alien]], [[summon devil]], [[touch of death]], and [[Drain life (monster attack)|drain life]], with an equal probability of each. A coven leader can only cast spells if [[Witch's familiar|her familiar]] is present, but is able to do so without any cooldown - if her familiar is killed, she gains +8 [[encouragement]] to damage and to-hit, and will eventually summon another familiar to replace the lost one.

==Generation==
Coven leaders are not randomly generated, and are not a valid form for polymorph.

At level creation, a single coven leader is generated in the Temples of the Old Gods within the [[Neutral Quest (dNetHack)|Neutral Quest]], with nine [[apprentice witch]]es and three witches accompanying her. A witch's familiar is generated alongside the coven leader at the same level as her.

A coven leader is [[Monster starting inventory|always generated with]] black [[high boots]], a [[plain dress]], a black set of [[leather armor]], a black [[Object properties#Defensive|magic-resistant]] [[Plain cloak|cloak]] (''not'' a [[cloak of magic resistance]]), a black [[pair of gloves]], a [[witch hat]], and a [[quarterstaff]].

The coven leader requires the most care of the witch battalion by far, on top of the familiars' [[open wounds]] spells cutting at you from across the river. Dealing with the witch battalion generally requires that characters have a high amount of HP and a source of [[half spell damage]].

==Origin==

European belief in witchcraft traces back to classical antiquity, with medieval and early modern European cultures playing host to [[Wikipedia:Witch hunt|witch hunting]]: the accused "witches" were usually women believed to have used black magic or maleficium against their own community, with the accusations borne of social tensions and believed by some anthropologists to have been focused on supposed enemies of the Church. Witchcraft is also generally considered malevolent in many indigenous belief systems, with people seeking healers and medicine people for protection against witchcraft. Believed to be driven by evil spirits or substances, suspected historical witches were intimidated, banished, attacked or outright killed - often they would be formally prosecuted and punished if they considered or simply believed to be guilty, resulting in tens of thousands of executions.

Witchcraft in its modern context generally refers to followers of certain types of modern paganism, who self-identify as witches and use the term witchcraft for their beliefs and practices, though some other neo-pagans avoid the term due to its negative connotations. Lovecraft]] short story "The Dreams in the Witch House", who is depicted as a servant of the alien [[wikipedia:Outer Gods|"Outer Gods"]].
